content.title: Carotid Shunting Indications During CEA
content.description: Decision-making regarding temporary shunt placement during carotid endarterectomy to maintain cerebral perfusion during carotid cross-clamping.
content.definition: Carotid shunting involves placing a temporary conduit (Argyle, Javid, Pruitt-Inhara) from the common carotid to internal carotid artery during CEA to maintain ipsilateral cerebral blood flow while the artery is clamped for endarterectomy.

shunting_philosophies: Routine shunting: All patients receive shunt
Selective shunting: Shunt based on monitoring/testing
No shunting: Rely on collateral flow, limit clamp time
selective_criteria: Awake testing: Neurologic changes with clamp trial

clinical_pearls: No RCT definitively proves one approach superior
Routine shunting adds 3-5 minutes but eliminates monitoring need
Selective shunting requires reliable monitoring method
Contralateral occlusion is most widely accepted absolute indication
Shunt rate typically 10-20% with selective approach
